Graphical abstract

A novel compound [CoL][Mn(ox)2]Cl⋅3H2O [L - N(CH2NHC2H4NH2)3, tris(((aminoethyl)amino)methyl)amine] (1), has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The compound 1 represents a rare example constructed by 1D polymeric   [ Mn ( ox   )   2     ]   n   2 n -     anions and [CoIIIL]3+ semisepulchrate-type cations. The advantages of the procedure elaborated include: one pot reaction, good efficiency and easily available starting materials.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel compound [CoL][Mn(ox)2]Cl⋅3H2O [L - N(CH2NHC2H4NH2)3, tris(((aminoethyl)amino)methyl)amine] (1), has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The compound 1 represents a new and rare example constructed by 1D polymeric   [ Mn ( ox   )   2     ]   n   2 n -     anions and semisepulchrate [CoIIIL]3+ cations. An efficient and simple procedure for the synthesis of 1 has been proposed. The advantages of this procedure include: one pot reaction, good efficiency and easily available starting materials.

</mml:math>, Solv – dmf, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH) has been studied. In the case of dmf solution [Co(en)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) was obtained, while in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH solution the Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>/Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> compound [CoL][Mn(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Cl·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (L – N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NHC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, tris(((aminoethyl)amino)methyl)amine) with a semisepulchrate cation was formed unexpectedly. Metal semisepulchrate complexes can be obtained <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> template reactions in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH solution of 3<ce:italic>d-</ce:italic>metal salts . However, the semisepulchrates complexes are difficult to isolate and only a few of them are described. We offer a novel efficient route to prepare Co/Mn heterometallic compounds with semisepulchrate entities in a one-pot procedure starting from metal Co powder and KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The direct synthesis is widely applied for elaboration of efficient routs operating with one pot reactions and easily available starting materials . Application of     MnO   4   -     as a source of Mn in direct synthesis of Cu/Mn heterometallic complexes has already proved to be a success . In order to obtain Co/Mn heterometallic compounds the system Co0-KMnO4-(NH4)2ox-en⋅2HCl-Solv (en - ethylenediamine,   ox -   C   2     O   4   2 -    , Solv - dmf, CH3OH) has been studied. In the case of dmf solution [Co(en)3]2[Mn2(ox)5]⋅6H2O (2) was obtained, while in CH3OH solution the CoIII/MnII compound [CoL][Mn(ox)2]Cl⋅3H2O (1) (L - N(CH2NHC2H4NH2)3, tris(((aminoethyl)amino)methyl)amine) with a semisepulchrate cation was formed unexpectedly. Metal semisepulchrate complexes can be obtained via template reactions in CH3OH solution of 3d-metal salts . However, the semisepulchrates complexes are difficult to isolate and only a few of them are described. We offer a novel efficient route to prepare Co/Mn heterometallic compounds with semisepulchrate entities in a one-pot procedure starting from metal Co powder and KMnO4 .

<ce:para view="all">The mechanism of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> formation is presumably multistage and sophisticated. A probable description is proposed below. It should be outlined that different stages of the synthesis most likely overlap and are not necessary consecutive. However, in order to simplify the discussion we give them formally as a set of separated processes. The first stage is the reduction of KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH accompanied by partial deprotonation of en·2HCl (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, (1)). This reaction is finished within first 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min of the synthesis, which is registered by the formation of a voluminous brown precipitate, presumably MnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and the solution decolouration. 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, which is a crucial reagent in the subsequent processes, forms per 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of <mml:math altimg="si5.gif" overflow="scroll">

elements.clean_text: The mechanism of 1 formation is presumably multistage and sophisticated. A probable description is proposed below. It should be outlined that different stages of the synthesis most likely overlap and are not necessary consecutive. However, in order to simplify the discussion we give them formally as a set of separated processes. The first stage is the reduction of KMnO4 by CH3OH accompanied by partial deprotonation of en⋅2HCl ( , (1)). This reaction is finished within first 2min of the synthesis, which is registered by the formation of a voluminous brown precipitate, presumably MnO2, and the solution decolouration. 1.5mol of CH2O, which is a crucial reagent in the subsequent processes, forms per 1mol of     MnO   4   -    .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The second stage is the Schiff reaction (, (2)). At the temperature of the synthesis the reaction is almost instantaneous. It is noteworthy that one-side azometinated en (L’·HCl, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol per 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of Co) is formed only, not twice azometinated, which affects the third stage flow greatly. It is caused by mono-deprotonation of en·2HCl at initial phases of the process and low content of CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol per 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of Co).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The second stage is the Schiff reaction (, (2)). At the temperature of the synthesis the reaction is almost instantaneous. It is noteworthy that one-side azometinated en (L'⋅HCl, 1.5mol per 1mol of Co) is formed only, not twice azometinated, which affects the third stage flow greatly. It is caused by mono-deprotonation of en⋅2HCl at initial phases of the process and low content of CH2O (1.5mol per 1mol of Co).

elements.clean_text: At the third stage Co0 dissolution (, (3)) occurs due to either Mn4+/Mn2+ redox potential or direct oxidation by atmospheric O2, followed by complexing with L' and transformation to Co3+ (, (4)). (The   [   CoL   3   '     ]   3 +     cation is sketched schematically, since Co3+ has an octahedral coordination environment). Then the template condensation of three coordinated L' ligands with ammonia occurs, resulting in the semisepulchrate Co3+ complex cation formation. The reaction terminates at the semisepulchrate formation due to two reasons: (i) a low rate of metallic Co powder dissolution and (ii) Co2+ in small concentrations comes into solution saturated with excess of L', which results in rapid formation of   [   CoL   3   '     ]   3 +     cation. The third stage is slow and conjugated with the subsequent one.

elements.clean_text:
At the final stage [CoL]3+ cations and   [ Mn ( ox   )   2     ]   n   2 n -     anions rapidly assemble into 1 and precipitate from the reaction system.

Impact of the in situ formation of CH2O on the identity of the reaction products is obvious and can be proved by substitution of CH3OH with dmf as a solvent in the synthetic procedure. It should be noted that 0.1mL of CH3OH was still added to the reaction mixture in the synthesis of [Co(en)3]2[Mn2(ox)5]⋅6H2O (2) to reduce     MnO   4   -     to MnO2, thus leading to the formation of CH2O. Due to different solvent properties of dmf if compared to CH3OH the condensation of en with CH2O and ammonia does not occur. As a result 2 forms, containing trivial [Co(en)3]3+ entities.

From X-ray single crystal analysis    [ Mn ( ox   )   2     ]   n   2 n -     anionic chains linked together by [CoL]3+ cations, water and Cl- anions form a H-bonded architecture in 1 ( ).

In the   [ Mn ( ox   )   2     ]   n   2 n -     helical chain running along the a axis each Mn atom is surrounded by six oxygen atoms from three oxalates. Two types of oxalato units are present: one is coordinated to the Mn atom and has two terminal O atoms [Mn-O 2.141(2)-2.171(2)Å], and another - a bis-chelating bridging oxalate that binds two Mn atoms [Mn-O 2.135(2)-2.143(2)Å]. The Mn(1)⋯Mn(1') distance through the bridging oxalate is 5.559Å which is shorter than the one in 2.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the [CoL]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cation, structurally similar to previously reported [ML] (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) , Co–N bond lengths [1.960(3)–1.979(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] and N–Co–N angles [85.45(11)–94.56(13)° for <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>- and 174.08(12)–174.68(12)° for <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-N atoms] are close to those reported earlier for compounds in Ref. .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the [CoL]3+ cation, structurally similar to previously reported [ML] (M=Co3+, Ni2+) , Co-N bond lengths [1.960(3)-1.979(3)Å] and N-Co-N angles [85.45(11)-94.56(13)° for cis- and 174.08(12)-174.68(12)° for trans-N atoms] are close to those reported earlier for compounds in Ref. .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the crystal the polymeric anions along with complex cations, located between them, form layered structure. Cations are bonded to anions by intermolecular hydrogen bonds between both coordinated and non-coordinated O atoms of terminal oxalates H-bonding to imino- and amino-groups of L. Layers of [CoL]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> are separated by layer formed by crystallization water molecules and chlorido anions bonded by the O–H⋯O and O–H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds. Two types of layers are connected by the N–H⋯Cl H-bonds with participation of the amino-group of L.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the crystal the polymeric anions along with complex cations, located between them, form layered structure. Cations are bonded to anions by intermolecular hydrogen bonds between both coordinated and non-coordinated O atoms of terminal oxalates H-bonding to imino- and amino-groups of L. Layers of [CoL]3+ are separated by layer formed by crystallization water molecules and chlorido anions bonded by the O-H⋯O and O-H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds. Two types of layers are connected by the N-H⋯Cl H-bonds with participation of the amino-group of L.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consists of [Co(en)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cations and [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6–</ce:sup> anions and water molecules. It should be noted that only a few anions of the formula [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> are known  and there are no Mn complexes among them. So, the [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6–</ce:sup> anion is crystallographically characterized for the first time. The structural blocks in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are linked together <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> a network of H-bonds, also involving crystallization water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). A distorted octahedral environment of each Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion is formed by one bridging and two terminal oxalato units.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 consists of [Co(en)3]3+ cations and [Mn2(ox)5]6- anions and water molecules. It should be noted that only a few anions of the formula [M2(ox)5] n  - are known  and there are no Mn complexes among them. So, the [Mn2(ox)5]6- anion is crystallographically characterized for the first time. The structural blocks in 2 are linked together via a network of H-bonds, also involving crystallization water molecules ( ). A distorted octahedral environment of each Mn2+ ion is formed by one bridging and two terminal oxalato units.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The Mn–ox<ce:sup loc="post">bridge</ce:sup> bond lengths [2.160(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] are slightly longer than those involving the terminal oxalato ligands [2.0888(19)–2.125(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å]. The Mn(1)⋯Mn(1′) distance through the bridging oxalate is 5.626<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Mn-oxbridge bond lengths [2.160(2)Å] are slightly longer than those involving the terminal oxalato ligands [2.0888(19)-2.125(2)Å]. The Mn(1)⋯Mn(1') distance through the bridging oxalate is 5.626Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the [Co(en)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cation the Co–N bond lengths [1.945(2)–1.974(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] and inter-ligand N–Co–N angles [85.08(10)–92.08(10)° for <ce:italic>cis-</ce:italic> and 175.06(15)–176.04(10)° for <ce:italic>trans-</ce:italic>N atoms] are in agreement with those found for similar complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the [Co(en)3]3+ cation the Co-N bond lengths [1.945(2)-1.974(2)Å] and inter-ligand N-Co-N angles [85.08(10)-92.08(10)° for cis- and 175.06(15)-176.04(10)° for trans-N atoms] are in agreement with those found for similar complexes .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Each [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6–</ce:sup> anion is linked to four [Co(en)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cations by H-bonds between the O atoms of terminal oxalato groups and NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-groups of ethylenediamine, forming stacks in [1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] direction. Those are reinforced by H-bonding water molecules located between neighboring anion and two cations. These stacks are shifted along the [2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0] direction by 1/2 cell unit and finally every [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6–</ce:sup> is surrounded by eight [Co(en)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each [Mn2(ox)5]6- anion is linked to four [Co(en)3]3+ cations by H-bonds between the O atoms of terminal oxalato groups and NH2-groups of ethylenediamine, forming stacks in [101] direction. Those are reinforced by H-bonding water molecules located between neighboring anion and two cations. These stacks are shifted along the [220] direction by 1/2 cell unit and finally every [Mn2(ox)5]6- is surrounded by eight [Co(en)3]3+ cations.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In conclusions, application of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH as a solvent in the system Co<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>–KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>–(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ox–en·2HCl–Solv leads to formation of semisepulchrate [CoL]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> complex due to <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> generation of CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, with the latter acting as a carbonyl component in template reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusions, application of CH3OH as a solvent in the system Co0-KMnO4-(NH4)2ox-en⋅2HCl-Solv leads to formation of semisepulchrate [CoL]3+ complex due to in situ generation of CH2O, with the latter acting as a carbonyl component in template reaction.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para view="all">All solvents and reagents were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. All experiments were carried out in air environment. Elemental analyses were performed with an ICP spectrometer (Fisons Instruments, ARL Model 3410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>) for Co and Mn and Perkin-Elmer 2400 Analyzer for C, H and N. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker 113v spectrometer from KBr pellets in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> region.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: All solvents and reagents were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. All experiments were carried out in air environment. Elemental analyses were performed with an ICP spectrometer (Fisons Instruments, ARL Model 3410+) for Co and Mn and Perkin-Elmer 2400 Analyzer for C, H and N. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker 113v spectrometer from KBr pellets in the 400-4000cm-1 region.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The mixture of cobalt powder (0.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (0.33<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were placed in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL conic flask. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 50–60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in open air for 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h until the total dissolution of Co was observed. The crude complex precipitated during the reaction was filtered off, washed with 2-propanol and dried in vacuo at room temperature. Recrystallization from H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gave orange crystals suitable for X-ray single crystal analysis. Yield 0.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (30% by cobalt). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">33</ce:inf>CoMnClN<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 25.48; H, 5.43; N, 16.00; Cl, 5.79; Co, 9.62; Mn, 8.97. Found: C, 25.2; H, 5.2; N, 15.9; Cl, 5.6; Co, 9.5; Mn, 8.8. IR (KBr discs, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3420br, 3247sh, 3216m, 3120br, 2989sh, 2906w, 2866w, 1620vs, 1468sh, 1446m, 1352m, 1315s, 1276w, 1242w, 1165m, 1136w, 1053m, 1018w, 981m, 906w, 840m, 783m, 713m, 609w, 586w, 499w, 445w.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1. The mixture of cobalt powder (0.07g, 1.25mmol), KMnO4 (0.2g, 1.25mmol), ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (0.33g, 2.5mmol), (NH4)2C2O4⋅H2O (0.36g, 2.5mmol), CH3OH (20mL) were placed in a 50mL conic flask. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 50-60°C in open air for 8h until the total dissolution of Co was observed. The crude complex precipitated during the reaction was filtered off, washed with 2-propanol and dried in vacuo at room temperature. Recrystallization from H2O gave orange crystals suitable for X-ray single crystal analysis. Yield 0.23g (30% by cobalt). Calc. for C13H33CoMnClN7O11: C, 25.48; H, 5.43; N, 16.00; Cl, 5.79; Co, 9.62; Mn, 8.97. Found: C, 25.2; H, 5.2; N, 15.9; Cl, 5.6; Co, 9.5; Mn, 8.8. IR (KBr discs, cm-1): 3420br, 3247sh, 3216m, 3120br, 2989sh, 2906w, 2866w, 1620vs, 1468sh, 1446m, 1352m, 1315s, 1276w, 1242w, 1165m, 1136w, 1053m, 1018w, 981m, 906w, 840m, 783m, 713m, 609w, 586w, 499w, 445w.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was carried out similarly to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> using dmf (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) as a solvent but with addition of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH as reducing agent. Yield 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (27% by cobalt). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>: C, 23.25; H, 5.32; N, 14.79; Co, 10.37; Mn, 9.67. Found: C, 23.2; H, 5.2; N, 14.6; Co, 10.3; Mn, 9.6. IR (KBr discs, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3500m, 3427m, 3204m, 3150sh, 3092m, 2967w, 1684sh, 1656s, 1618s, 1579sh, 1554m, 1461w, 1420m, 1369w, 1343w, 1335m, 1318sh, 1284m, 1247w, 1190w, 1157w, 1120w, 1055m, 995w, 880w, 780m, 774m, 578w, 495m, 437w.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 2. The synthesis of 2 was carried out similarly to 1 using dmf (20mL) as a solvent but with addition of 0.1mL of CH3OH as reducing agent. Yield 0.38g (27% by cobalt). Calc. for C22H60Co2Mn2N12O26: C, 23.25; H, 5.32; N, 14.79; Co, 10.37; Mn, 9.67. Found: C, 23.2; H, 5.2; N, 14.6; Co, 10.3; Mn, 9.6. IR (KBr discs, cm-1): 3500m, 3427m, 3204m, 3150sh, 3092m, 2967w, 1684sh, 1656s, 1618s, 1579sh, 1554m, 1461w, 1420m, 1369w, 1343w, 1335m, 1318sh, 1284m, 1247w, 1190w, 1157w, 1120w, 1055m, 995w, 880w, 780m, 774m, 578w, 495m, 437w.

<ce:simple-para view="all">Diffraction data were collected on a Xcalibur-3 diffractometer (ω and θ scans) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The data were corrected for Lorentz-polarization effects and for the effects of absorption (multi-scans method). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELX-97 package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The assignment of each of the metal atoms is based on refinement and on comparison of the bond lengths with the literature values. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined within a riding model, with <ce:italic>U</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">iso</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>nU</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eq</ce:inf> of the carrier atom (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5 for water molecules and methyl groups, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.2 for the remaining H-atoms). In structure <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> two strong electron density peaks were found in the area between complexes and were assigned to water molecules. All attempts to locate meaningful positions of other non-hydrogen atoms of solvent were unsuccessful. Therefore, in the final refinement, the contribution from the solvent was eliminated using SQUEESE procedure implemented in PLATON program . elements.clean_text: Diffraction data were collected on a Xcalibur-3 diffractometer (ω and θ scans) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were corrected for Lorentz-polarization effects and for the effects of absorption (multi-scans method). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELX-97 package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The assignment of each of the metal atoms is based on refinement and on comparison of the bond lengths with the literature values. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined within a riding model, with U iso = nU eq of the carrier atom (n =1.5 for water molecules and methyl groups, n =1.2 for the remaining H-atoms). In structure 2 two strong electron density peaks were found in the area between complexes and were assigned to water molecules. All attempts to locate meaningful positions of other non-hydrogen atoms of solvent were unsuccessful. Therefore, in the final refinement, the contribution from the solvent was eliminated using SQUEESE procedure implemented in PLATON program . The values of selected geometrical parameters are listed in the supplementary materials. Crystal data for 1 . C13H33ClCoMnN7O11, M =612.78, triclinic, space group   P   1   ¯    , T =100(2)K, a =9.7368(3)Å, b =9.9048(2)Å, c =14.3865(3)Å, α =105.882(2)°, β =99.604(4)°, γ =110.632(3)°, V =1194.29(7)Å3, Z =2, ρcalc  =1.704gcm-1, μ =1.402mm-1, F(000)=634, reflections: measured/independent/observed=12,067/5272/4613, R int =0.0166, R [I >2σ(I)]=0.0492, wR (F 2)=0.1237 and 319 parameters. Crystal data for 2 . C22H60Co2Mn2N12O26, M =1136.56, monoclinic, space group C2/m, T =294(2)K, a =13.6752(2)Å, b =21.7205(3)Å, c =8.39320(10)Å, β =104.3370(10)°, V =2415.41(6)Å3, Z =2, ρcalc  =1.563gcm-1, μ =1.278mm-1, F(000)=1176, reflections: measured/independent/observed=29,836/3595/3055, R int =0.0257, R [I >2σ(I)]=0.0516, wR (F 2)=0.1452 and 149 parameters. CCDC reference number 676865 (1), 676866 (2).

<ce:para view="all">The mechanism of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> formation is presumably multistage and sophisticated. A probable description is proposed below. It should be outlined that different stages of the synthesis most likely overlap and are not necessary consecutive. However, in order to simplify the discussion we give them formally as a set of separated processes. The first stage is the reduction of KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH accompanied by partial deprotonation of en·2HCl (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, (1)). This reaction is finished within first 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min of the synthesis, which is registered by the formation of a voluminous brown precipitate, presumably MnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and the solution decolouration. 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, which is a crucial reagent in the subsequent processes, forms per 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of <mml:math altimg="si5.gif" overflow="scroll">

</mml:math>.</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The mixture of cobalt powder (0.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (0.33<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were placed in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL conic flask. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 50–60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in open air for 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h until the total dissolution of Co was observed. The crude complex precipitated during the reaction was filtered off, washed with 2-propanol and dried in vacuo at room temperature. Recrystallization from H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gave orange crystals suitable for X-ray single crystal analysis. Yield 0.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (30% by cobalt). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">33</ce:inf>CoMnClN<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 25.48; H, 5.43; N, 16.00; Cl, 5.79; Co, 9.62; Mn, 8.97. Found: C, 25.2; H, 5.2; N, 15.9; Cl, 5.6; Co, 9.5; Mn, 8.8. Yield 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (27% by cobalt). cln_elements.clean_text:
The mechanism of 1 formation is presumably multistage and sophisticated. A probable description is proposed below. It should be outlined that different stages of the synthesis most likely overlap and are not necessary consecutive. However, in order to simplify the discussion we give them formally as a set of separated processes. The first stage is the reduction of KMnO4 by CH3OH accompanied by partial deprotonation of en⋅2HCl ( , (1)). This reaction is finished within first 2min of the synthesis, which is registered by the formation of a voluminous brown precipitate, presumably MnO2, and the solution decolouration. 1.5mol of CH2O, which is a crucial reagent in the subsequent processes, forms per 1mol of     MnO   4   -    .

Synthesis of 1. The mixture of cobalt powder (0.07g, 1.25mmol), KMnO4 (0.2g, 1.25mmol), ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (0.33g, 2.5mmol), (NH4)2C2O4⋅H2O (0.36g, 2.5mmol), CH3OH (20mL) were placed in a 50mL conic flask. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 50-60°C in open air for 8h until the total dissolution of Co was observed. The crude complex precipitated during the reaction was filtered off, washed with 2-propanol and dried in vacuo at room temperature. Recrystallization from H2O gave orange crystals suitable for X-ray single crystal analysis. Yield 0.23g (30% by cobalt). Calc. for C13H33CoMnClN7O11: C, 25.48; H, 5.43; N, 16.00; Cl, 5.79; Co, 9.62; Mn, 8.97. Found: C, 25.2; H, 5.2; N, 15.9; Cl, 5.6; Co, 9.5; Mn, 8.8. IR (KBr discs, cm-1): 3420br, 3247sh, 3216m, 3120br, 2989sh, 2906w, 2866w, 1620vs, 1468sh, 1446m, 1352m, 1315s, 1276w, 1242w, 1165m, 1136w, 1053m, 1018w, 981m, 906w, 840m, 783m, 713m, 609w, 586w, 499w, 445w.

Synthesis of 2. The synthesis of 2 was carried out similarly to 1 using dmf (20mL) as a solvent but with addition of 0.1mL of CH3OH as reducing agent. Yield 0.38g (27% by cobalt). Calc. for C22H60Co2Mn2N12O26: C, 23.25; H, 5.32; N, 14.79; Co, 10.37; Mn, 9.67. Found: C, 23.2; H, 5.2; N, 14.6; Co, 10.3; Mn, 9.6. IR (KBr discs, cm-1): 3500m, 3427m, 3204m, 3150sh, 3092m, 2967w, 1684sh, 1656s, 1618s, 1579sh, 1554m, 1461w, 1420m, 1369w, 1343w, 1335m, 1318sh, 1284m, 1247w, 1190w, 1157w, 1120w, 1055m, 995w, 880w, 780m, 774m, 578w, 495m, 437w.

cln_elements.clean_text: Diffraction data were collected on a Xcalibur-3 diffractometer (ω and θ scans) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were corrected for Lorentz-polarization effects and for the effects of absorption (multi-scans method). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELX-97 package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The assignment of each of the metal atoms is based on refinement and on comparison of the bond lengths with the literature values. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined within a riding model, with U iso = nU eq of the carrier atom (n =1.5 for water molecules and methyl groups, n =1.2 for the remaining H-atoms). In structure 2 two strong electron density peaks were found in the area between complexes and were assigned to water molecules. All attempts to locate meaningful positions of other non-hydrogen atoms of solvent were unsuccessful. Therefore, in the final refinement, the contribution from the solvent was eliminated using SQUEESE procedure implemented in PLATON program . The values of selected geometrical parameters are listed in the supplementary materials. Crystal data for 1 . C13H33ClCoMnN7O11, M =612.78, triclinic, space group   P   1   ¯    , T =100(2)K, a =9.7368(3)Å, b =9.9048(2)Å, c =14.3865(3)Å, α =105.882(2)°, β =99.604(4)°, γ =110.632(3)°, V =1194.29(7)Å3, Z =2, ρcalc  =1.704gcm-1, μ =1.402mm-1, F(000)=634, reflections: measured/independent/observed=12,067/5272/4613, R int =0.0166, R [I >2σ(I)]=0.0492, wR (F 2)=0.1237 and 319 parameters. Crystal data for 2 . C22H60Co2Mn2N12O26, M =1136.56, monoclinic, space group C2/m, T =294(2)K, a =13.6752(2)Å, b =21.7205(3)Å, c =8.39320(10)Å, β =104.3370(10)°, V =2415.41(6)Å3, Z =2, ρcalc  =1.563gcm-1, μ =1.278mm-1, F(000)=1176, reflections: measured/independent/observed=29,836/3595/3055, R int =0.0257, R [I >2σ(I)]=0.0516, wR (F 2)=0.1452 and 149 parameters. CCDC reference number 676865 (1), 676866 (2).
